Description: Latvians were banned from tourism to Russia and BelarusLatvian Parliament on Thursday decided to ban tourist trips to Russia and Belarus. The decision is aimed at reducing the risk of human rights violations against Latvian citizens in these countries, as well as preventing them from being recruited as spies, authorities say. The initiator of the ban was the New Unity party. Party deputy Gatis Lipi≈° stressed that trips to Russia and Belarus pose a security threat. Description: ASTRA: The owner of the tanker -Volgoneft 239- was fined 300 thousand rubles for violating technical regulationsThe Arbitration Court of the Krasnodar Territory made a decision in the case of violation of technical regulations by the owner of the tanker -Volgoneft 239-, which wreckedin the Kerch Strait. The company Volgatransneft CJSC was fined 300 thousand rubles. The court found the company guilty of violating the rules for operating mixed-type vessels, since the tanker continued to sail after the expiration of the season and outside the established navigation area, which is contrary to the requirements of Russian legislation.CJSC Volgatransneft plans to appeal the decision.-Guilty is proven when the shipowner has the opportunity to fulfill the requirements of the law, but did not comply with them. We referred in court to the fact that we did not have the opportunity to comply with these legal requirements. We believe that it is not entirely correct to place all the blame on the shipowner for this situation, because, firstly, on December 5, the ship was released on the instructions of the captain of the port of Kavkaz. The passage as part of a caravan was allowed, and after crossing the Kerch Strait, the ship, without unloading, could no longer return back to the Sea of ‚Äã‚ÄãAzov under any circumstances,- RIA Novosti quotes company representative Olga Pautova.An environmental disaster in the Black Sea occurred on December 15, 2024 in the Kerch Strait, when two tankers, Volgoneft 212- and -Volgoneft 239-, transporting fuel oil, crashed. As a result of the incident, significant pollution of the sea occurred: about 2.4 thousand tons of fuel oil got into the waters of the strait from four damaged tanks about 2.4 thousand tons of fuel oil. This led to the release of oil products on the coast of the Krasnodar Territory and the Crimean Peninsula, which provoked the introduction of emergency regimes both at regional level, and at federal.

Title: üñº An official from Komi, accused of corruption, asks to go to wa...
Description: An official from Komi, accused of corruption, asks to go to war with UkraineFormer first deputy head of the administration of the city of Pechora in the Komi Republic, Andrei Kanishchev, who is under investigation on charges of corruption, signed a contract with the Russian Ministry of Defense and expressed his intention to go to the zone of a special military operation in Ukraine. A corresponding petition to suspend the criminal case was received by the Pechora City Court, but at the moment it has not yet been considered, local media writes.  Kanishchev is accused of receiving a bribe on an especially large scale and exceeding official authority. According to investigators, he, together with the former mayor of Pechora Valery Serov, received a bribe in the amount of four million rubles from a commercial company for assistance in concluding a government contract to carry out work to improve the city. At the time of the initiation of this criminal case, Kanishchev was already in custody on another charge. In February 2024, he was sentenced to 10 years in prison for intentionally causing grievous bodily harm, negligently resulting in the death of the victim. In August 2022, Kanishchev hit sound engineer Viktor Fateev during a fire show on the main stage of Pechora, which led to his death. The case of Kanishchev is notsingle. Since the beginning of Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, 108 Russian officials and deputies have declared their desire to go to the front. Of these, 70 did this voluntarily, and 18, who were under criminal prosecution, chose to avoid it by signing contracts with the Ministry of Defense. The remaining 20 people subsequently abandoned their intentions.In March 2023, the mayor of Vorkuta, Yaroslav Shaposhnikov, announced that he would go to war in Ukraine. But he did this only after 118 days, citing the fact that the then acting head of Komi, Vladimir Uyba, asked him to stay.In May 2023, the acting Minister of Health of Komi, Igor Diaghilev, voluntarily went to the front, where he worked as a traumatologist in a military hospital. A year and a half later, in October 2024, after his return, he was appointed deputy prime minister of the government of the republic.The former first deputy head of the administration of Syktyvkar, Alexander Mozhegov, also found himself in the combat zone. The reasons for his participation in the war were not officially reported.Another official from Komi, ex-head of the Kortkeros district Alexander Arteev, came to the front from a penal colony. In 2023, he was sentenced to 13 years in prison for accepting bribes. In July 2024, his death became known.

Description: The court upheld the sentence of a resident of the Saratov region who returned from the war for beating up his neighborsThe permanent judicial presence of the Central District Military Court in Samara upheld the sentence of a participant in the war in Ukraine Dmitry Kiryukhin from Atkarsk, Saratov region, who was previously convicted of attacking his neighbors. He was also charged with using violence against a government official (Article 318 of the Criminal Code of the Russian Federation) and insulting a police officer (Article 319 of the Criminal Code of the Russian Federation).On June 28, 2024, the Saratov Garrison Military Court sentenced Kiryukhin to four years in prison and a fine of 30 thousand rubles. The prosecutor's office asked for six years in prison. The lawyers appealed the verdict, but on February 12, Judge Stanislav Makarov left it unchanged, write -Free News-.At the trial Kiryukhin admitted guilt, explaining that he committed the attack while intoxicated and -out of hooligan motives.- He also expressed a desire, after the verdict, to sign a new contract with the Russian Ministry of Defense and go to the front again.Kiryukhin's neighbors filed civil claims against him for compensation for moral damage in the amount of five million rubles. Description: Political prisoners will not be included in the May amnestyDeputies of the Communist Party faction led by Gennady Zyuganov submitted to the State Duma a draft resolution on an amnesty dedicated to the 80th anniversary of Victory in the Great Patriotic War, writes TASS. The document provides for the release from punishment of persons convicted for the first time for intentional crimes of minor and moderate gravity, as well as certain categories of citizens, including combatants, home front workers, minors, pregnant women and disabled people of groups I and II. However, the draft contains exceptions for a number of articles of the Criminal Code of the Russian Federation, to which the amnesty does not apply. Among them are articles 280.3 (repeated discrediting of the Armed Forces of the Russian Federation), 207.3 (public dissemination of knowingly false information about the use of the RF Armed Forces) and 205.2 (public calls for terrorist activities or public justification of terrorism). Thus, persons convicted under these articles are not subject to the proposed amnesty, even if they belong to preferential categories such as pregnant women, single parents or pensioners.Previously, some deputies from the United Russia party expressed the opinion that holding an amnesty this year is inappropriate, since the convicts can -atone for their guilt- by signing a contract and going to war with Ukraine.Last A large-scale amnesty in Russia, dedicated to the 70th anniversary of the Victory, was carried out in 2015 and affected about 60 thousand people sentenced to imprisonment and up to 200 thousand suspended sentences. The final decision on the amnesty and its conditions will be made after consideration and discussion of the project in the State Duma.

Title: üñº Russian military spending has exceeded the defense budgets of ...
Description: Russian military spending has exceeded the defense budgets of all European countriesAccording to data from the International Institute for Strategic Studies (IISS), published on February 12, 2025, Russian military spending in 2024 increased by 42% and reached 13.1 trillion rubles, which is equivalent to $462 billion at purchasing power parity. This amount exceeds the combined defense budgets of all European Union countries and the United Kingdom, which grew by 12% in 2024 to $457 billion, reports the Financial Times. In absolute terms, the largest European defense budgets in 2024 were Germany ($86 billion), the United Kingdom ($81 billion) and France ($64 billion). As a percentage of GDP, the most significant defense expenditures were borne by Estonia (4% of GDP) and Poland (3.25% of GDP), although their absolute costs were less: $1.7 billion and $28 billion, respectively. According to IISS forecasts, in 2025, Russian military spending will increase by 13.7%, reaching 15.6 trillion rubles, which will amount to 7.5% of the country's GDP and almost 40% of the federal budget.

Description: Ukrainian citizens accused of sabotage were sentenced to 23 years in prisonThe First Western District Military Court sentenced Ukrainian citizens Alexander Maystruk and Eduard Usatenko to 23 years in prison on charges of sabotage at facilities energy infrastructure of Russia, reports SOTA vision. According to the case materials, they were part of a sabotage and terrorist group of the Foreign Intelligence Service of Ukraine. The investigation believes that on the eve of Victory Day in 2023, Maystruk and Usatenko blew up one and mined four power transmission towers of the Leningrad Nuclear Power Plant, and also planted explosive devices under seven towers of the Kalinin Nuclear Power Plant. Maystruk and Usatenko, according to investigators, were recruited by an employee of the Foreign Intelligence Service of Ukraine and underwent special training in camps in the Kyiv and Nikolaev regions. Then they illegally crossed the Russian-Belarusian border in the Pskov region, arriving from the territory of Ukraine in transit through Poland and Belarus. The investigation believes that in total Maystruk and Usatenko tried to blow up more than 30 supports of high-voltage power lines at the Leningrad and Kalinin nuclear power plants to stop nuclear reactors and disrupt the normal operation of the nuclear power plant. In addition to Maistruk and Usatenko, the FSB detained two Russian acquaintances who assisted them in providing them with communications equipment and vehicles with fake state registration plates.The court hearings were held behind closed doors. According to the press service of the St. Petersburg courts, Maystruk and Usatenko admitted their guilt. The damage from their actions is estimated at 10.85 million rubles. According to the court's decision, the convicts will spend the first five years in prison and the remaining term in a maximum security colony. In addition, they are required to pay a fine of 10 million rubles. This case was the first in the history of the First Western District Military Court in which the defendants were charged with undergoing training for the purpose of carrying out sabotage and terrorist activities. The indictment included articles on committing a terrorist attack, attempted terrorist attack and sabotage, illegal trafficking in weapons and explosives, as well as their smuggling.

Title: üñº In 2024, more than 2,600 people were killed as a result of she...
Description: In 2024, shelling in Ukraine and Russia killed more than 2,600 people, - CITIn 2024, shelling in Ukraine and Russia killed at least 2,600 people, including 115 children, and injured more than 14,000 people, including 842 children. This is stated in the Conflict Intelligence Team report, based on data from official departments, media reports and information from open sources.In the Kyiv-controlled territories of Ukraine, 1915 people died, including 81 children. 10,164 people were injured. According to him, it will have many benefits and high monetary support. -Details will be made public soon, in the coming days,- - transmits channel 24. -This is for those who want to join the army. And it may very well be that today he will continue to improve his position, and the command, in order to hide another lie of recent months, will again begin to drive soldiers without training, increasing losses.-Alekhine especially harshly criticizes General Sukhrab Akhmedov, whose departure from the 20th Army, according to the author, became a real holiday for everyone. He notes that his mistakes, like the mistakes of other generals, continue to cost dearly on the battlefield.Previously, Z-channels accused General Akhmedov of giving away in June 2023 orderto line up Russian military personnel in the Kremennaya area, preparing them for action - as a result, the Ukrainian Armed Forces struck a military concentration with a HIMARS missile. The Marines of the 155th Brigade also mentioned Akhmedov in their complaint to the governor of Primorsky Krai, in which they expressed dissatisfaction with the command and huge losses near Pavlovka in Donetsk region.In December 2023, Putin signed a decree awarding Akhmedov the rank of lieutenant general.

Title: The Belarusian Gayun project, which monitors military activity, a...
Description: The Belarusian Gayun project, which monitors military activity, announced the cessation of work. A few days before, the team reported that the bot had been hackedThe message about the closure appeared in the official channel of the project. On February 5, -Belarusski Gayun- reported about the hacking of the feedback bot. The creator of the channel, Anton Motolko, wrote: -I want to say right away that human error was at work in this situation, and this error was mine. If you sent information that could identify you or posted from accounts that could identify you, you are at risk.- Belarusian security forces soon reported their first arrest due to the leak. The Digital Intelligence Team identified him as 42-year-old Maxim Nikitenko, a native of Mozyr. In recent years, he worked at the Mozyr oil refinery. He has a wife and two children. Belaruski Gayun monitored military activity in Belarus, recording the movement of troops, aircraft and equipment. After the start of the Russian-Ukrainian war, he published data about the Russian Armed Forces. In March 2022, the channel was declared extremist.

Title: The court ordered Valeria Guiva, a graduate of the St. Petersburg...
Description: The court ordered Valeria Guiva, a graduate of the St. Petersburg Chemical-Pharmaceutical University, to return to the state three times the amount of the scholarship for six years of study due to her refusal to work as assigned in MariupolThe press service of the courts of St. Petersburg reports this.Guiva studied at the Faculty of Pharmacy under a targeted training agreement with the Southern District Medical Center Federal Medical and Biological Agency, writes -Paper-. The medical center opened two branches in the occupied territories of Ukraine, one of which is located in Mariupol, from where Guiva‚Äôs employment application was received.After the graduate refused to work in Mariupol, the university filed a lawsuit to recover the scholarship for the entire period of study. The court upheld the claim, obliging Guiva and her family to return to the state three times the amount of the scholarship received‚Äîthat‚Äôs 168.5 thousand rubles, plus a fine of 337 thousand rubles. Its size corresponds to twice the amount of the scholarship received during the study.
